webTitle: Australia's GDP has risen again – here are six things you need to know

fields.standfirst: The headline figures are looking pretty good but a little more digging reveals an economy that is not necessarily as healthy as it might appear
fields.body:
The quarterly national accounts figures give us a chance to give the Australian economy a bit of a physical examination and see how healthy it is.

1. Overall growth is strong, but nominal growth remains weak

The headline GDP figures are always eye-catching. And here the trend annual real GDP growth of 3.2% is right on the 25-year average. It was also an increase from the March quarter of 3.1%. In the more erratic seasonally adjusted terms, real GDP grew 3.1%, down from 3.3% in the March quarter but still looking quite good.

And yet quarterly growth of GDP has been slowing this year. So part of the reason the annual growth looks to be improving is that the first half of last year was so poor that it doesn’t take much to improve on it.

Annual per capita GDP growth is 1.7% – slightly below the 25-year average of 1.8%.

So all healthy?

Well sort of. When we get to nominal GDP, we reach a point where the doctor might be asking for a nurse to come in and assist. The annual growth is a mere 4%, which is well below the 25-year average of 6.1%.

This is a concern given the link between nominal GDP growth and taxation revenue. But the impact might not be too great because the May budget predicted nominal GDP in 2014-15 would grow just 3%. It also predicted in 2013-14 it would grow 4% – on that score the Treasury was spot on.

2. So about that export boom ...

Three months ago things looked great. Exports were booming – up 9.6% – and net exports (exports minus imports) contributed 1.2 percentage points to GDP growth.

Crack open the champagne, the transition from investment to export boom was done!

And then this quarter exports fell 0.8% in seasonally adjusted terms, and annual growth dropped to 5.4%:

And rather than help growth, net exports actually detracted 0.9 percentage points from GDP growth in the June quarter:

The trend figure was less drastic, but it still points to a pause on the export boom.

This wasn’t unexpected – as I noted last week, the Reserve Bank was expecting exports to fall this quarter. But it does highlight that an export boom is not guaranteed to be as steady and strong as the investment boom, especially when export prices are falling.

The Bureau of Statistics noted the terms of trade (the prices for our exports compared with our imports) fell for the 12th straight quarter:

They are now 20% below where they were three years ago – marking the biggest three-year drop ever, surpassing the 17% fall that occurred in the mid-1970s when the Opec oil crises jacked up the price of oil.

3. Mining still the leader of the pack, but ...

So if exports fell, why is the mining industry still the biggest contributor to GDP growth?

Inventories.

Inventories are essentially stock that companies have produced but have not sold, and the last quarter saw a very strong increase in inventories.

This is a good thing if companies are running up inventories because they anticipate strong future sales. I suspect this is part of the issue. Companies have been producing goods but because exports were down this past quarter they haven’t sold as much as they may have hoped, but they still think they will.

In March the change in inventories detracted from growth, while net exports added to it. This time around it is the opposite.

But the mining industry, which increased its inventories by easily the largest amount, remains the big dog in the economy.

In the past year it contributed 1.2 percentage points to GDP growth – double the next best industry.

But the June quarter saw a 1.4% fall in the seasonally adjusted mining gross value added. This is the biggest quarterly fall since 2011, and the fifth biggest in the past decade.

And while the annual growth of mining gross value added continues to rise, the fall in the seasonally adjusted figure suggests the mining industry’s performance for the moment is greatly tied to exports.

4. Housing is helping New South Wales, but business investment is hurting the west

When we examine the growth in investment, the big winner is housing. Private dwelling investment increased 3.2% in the June quarter and 9.5% in the past year.

But non-dwelling investment, whether it be construction or investing in machinery and equipment, has been falling. And overall, total business investment fell 7.1% over the 12 months to June.

The strong housing investment is naturally helping the state with the biggest housing boom going at the moment, NSW. And NSW’s state final demand reported the strongest growth of all states over the past year.

It also means that NSW’s final demand is adding more to national GDP than any other state.

While Western Australia’s final demand has now fallen for seven straight quarters, this doesn’t mean it is in a recession, or is not assisting GDP growth. Exports are not counted in state final demand. But the lack of growth does highlight that the days of WA massively drawing production from other states is over.

5. The workers keep working well

Productivity again showed a nice improvement. The annual growth of gross value added per hour worked in the market sector (which is all sectors except health, education and the public administration sector) grew 3.3%, the best result for two years.

The five-year growth rate – which is a more sensible way to look at the issue of long-term productivity growth – has it running at 12.8%, just down from the 13% recorded in the March quarter. This is as good as it has been in a decade.

At this point we shall pause, while business leaders take to the street celebrating the result and rescinding their demands that the government change the industrial relations system in order to stop the decline in productivity.

Or not.

6. Final result: see us again in three months

As with most doctor visits, there’s a bit of wait and see involved with examining the GDP figures.

The rise in inventories suggests businesses are confident they will be able to sell that stock in the future. The decline in exports after the massively strong March quarter was not unexpected, but it’s not something you want to become a trend.

The low interest rates continue to see strong housing growth, especially in NSW, but other parts of the country aren’t faring as well. And overall, while GDP growth is right on average, it has the look of slowing rather than speeding up.

The falling terms of trade look set to continue, which means while the amount we export might keep going up, the amount of money we earn from that may not increase as much.

And I’ll leave you with one final graph – the annual growth of real net national disposable income. This is a good way to look at the improvement in our living standards.

In the past year it grew just 1.7% overall and a mere 0.1% in per capita terms. While this is an improvement from the past year, it is massively down on the 25-year average of a 2% per capita annual increase.

The whole economy may be growing at a nice average rate, but with incomes barely growing at all, it’s not surprising if people don’t feel as though the economy is completely healthy.
